"The International Relations Committee has succeeded in getting several series
of excellent programs from other countries and has handled the details connected
with the Association’s entries in the PRIX ITALIA contest.
"The Professional Advancement Committee has done great service in the past
couple of years in screening and selecting winners of NAEB scholarships and par¬
ticipants in the three TV Production Workshops.
"And of course possibly the hardest working committees are those concerned
with the operation of the Network. These committees screen and select the programs
that are carried by the Network and discuss new program possibilities.
"Now we are planning for the future. Our relations with the various founda¬
tions, especially the W, K. Kellogg Foundation which made the original grant which
made possible the establishment of the Headquarters and Network, and the Fund for
Adult Education which has made possible our Engineering, Placement, Management
Relations, and Consultation Team services as well as our professional advancement
program, are excellent. These grants have enabled some of the dreams of educa¬
tional broadcasters to become realities. Our future plans envision expanded serv¬
ices, continued cooperation with "sister" organizations and some sort of Washington
representation. None of these can become realities without the active and enthu¬
siastic support and cooperation of all members. And we welcome, in fact need, your
suggestions and criticisms at all times."
Chairman Smith called for questions to be directed to Dr. Skornia. The follow¬
ing questions and answers are representative:
Question: Are there any particular mechanics one must go through for a request
for an NAEB grant?
Answer: There is a form of letter for requesting a grant that is sent to the
acceptance committee.
